questions.text: Which antibodies are characterized against Mucocutaneous Pemphigus Vulgaris? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Desmoglein 1 and 3.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucocutaneous Pemphigus vulgaris requires antibodies against both Desmoglein 1 and 3, with Desmoglein-3 antibodies typically being predominant; this combined antibody profile explains the involvement of both skin and mucous membranes.
  • ➤ Mucocutaneous Pemphigus vulgaris requires antibodies against both Desmoglein 1 and 3, with Desmoglein-3 antibodies typically being predominant; this combined antibody profile explains the involvement of both skin and mucous membranes.
  • ➤ Mucocutaneous Pemphigus vulgaris
  • ➤ both Desmoglein 1 and 3,

questions.text: Which tendons are involved in the test shown below?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) APL and EPB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons are inflamed in the condition called De Quervain Tenosynovitis. The diagnostic special test for the condition is called Finkelstein Test as shown in the image in the question.
  • ➤ Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons are inflamed in the condition called De Quervain Tenosynovitis.
  • ➤ The diagnostic special test for the condition is called Finkelstein Test as shown in the image in the question.

questions.text: As per the latest MTP act, termination of failed contraception is allowed till which weeks of contraception? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 20 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The MTP Act permits termination of pregnancy due to failed contraception up to 20 weeks.

questions.text: Clonorchis sinensis is associated with which type of cancer? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Opisthorchis viverrini is the new name of Clonorchis sinensis. It is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program to a 10-year-old school child?( NEET PG 2021 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) TT/Td

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: Which of the following is the best test for long-term control of diabetes? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HbA1C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HbA1C is the best test for evaluating long-term control of diabetes, providing an average of blood glucose levels over the past 2 to 3 months.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is in labor, and her cardiotocogram (CTG) is shown. What does this CTG indicate? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Early decelerations

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early decelerations are characterized by symmetrical drops in fetal heart rate with the nadir coinciding with the peak of uterine contractions, caused by head compression during labor, and are considered physiological

questions.text: True statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable

options.label: C
options.text: Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels

options.label: D
options.text: Point B to D is refractory period

questions.correct_answer: D. Point B to D is refractory period
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Point B to D is refractory period

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period.
  • • AT POINT 1 - Resting membrane potential: membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels are closed.
  • • AT POINT 1
  • • AT POINT 2 - Membrane depolarization: Na+ activation gate opens à Na+ flows inward.
  • • AT POINT 2 -
  • • AT POINT 3 - Membrane repolarization: Na+ inactivation gate closes at peak potential, thus stopping Na+ inflow. K+ activation gate opens → K+ flows outward.
  • • AT POINT 3
  • • AT POINT 4 - Membrane hyperpolarization: K+ activation gates are slow to close → excess K+ efflux and brief period of hyperpolarization. Voltage-gated Na+ channels switch back to resting state. Na+/K+ pump restores ions concentration.
  • • AT POINT 4 -
  • • Point 2 to 4 is a part of the refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.
  • • Point 2 to 4
  • • The refractory period is divided into two, an absolute refractory period and a relative refractory period. During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given. However, during the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Incorrect. Threshold potential is reached just before point B where a rapid depolarization phase begins.
  • • Option A
  • • Option B : Incorrect. At point E, the nerve is not more excitable; rather, it is in a hyperpolarized state where more than the normal stimulus would be needed to generate another action potential.
  • • Option B
  • • Option C : Incorrect. The transition from C to D is characterized by the closing of Na+ channels and the opening of K+ channels, not the other way around.
  • • Option C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The phases of an action potential -
  • ➤ Point A : Represents the resting membrane potential. Point B : Marks the threshold potential.
  • ➤ Point A : Represents the resting membrane potential.
  • ➤ Point A
  • ➤ Point B : Marks the threshold potential.
  • ➤ Point B
  • ➤ Point C : Represents the peak of the action potential.
  • ➤ Point C
  • ➤ Point D : Repolarization phase Point E : Hyperpolarization phase Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C Relative refractory period from around point C to D
  • ➤ Point D : Repolarization phase
  • ➤ Point D
  • ➤ Point E : Hyperpolarization phase
  • ➤ Point E
  • ➤ Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C
  • ➤ Absolute refractory period
  • ➤ Relative refractory period from around point C to D
  • ➤ Relative refractory period

questions.text: Fatty acid transport through mitochondrial membrane is via? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Carnitine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fatty acid transport through the mitochondrial membrane involves the carnitine shuttle system. Long-chain fatty acids are activated to form fatty acyl-CoA in the cytoplasm. Carnitine acyltransferase I (CAT I) then catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming fatty acyl-carnitine.
  • ➤ Fatty acyl-carnitine is transported across the mitochondrial membrane via a carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase.Once inside the mitochondrial matrix, carnitine acyltransferase II (CAT II) catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group back to CoA, allowing the fatty acid to undergo β-oxidation.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 208

questions.text: A 62-year-old elderly male presented with persistent fatigue and lymph total leucocyte count of 50,000/µl. His peripheral smear was done and had the findings as shown. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a suspected case of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), especially with the presence of smudge cells on a peripheral smear, flow cytometry is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea?( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Endothelium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The corneal endothelium is crucial for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea through active ion pumping mechanisms, ensuring proper hydration levels to prevent light scattering and maintain clarity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with painful oral mucosal lesions and blisters on her skin. A biopsy is performed, and direct immunofluorescence microscopy is used to examine the skin specimen. Based on this finding, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris presents with painful oral lesions and skin blisters, and its hallmark DIF finding is the fishnet pattern due to antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3.

questions.text: Function of IL-8 is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Chemotaxis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary function of IL-8 is to induce chemotaxis, particularly attracting neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer develops diffuse hair loss following the treatment. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anagen effluvium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chemotherapy-induced hair loss is due to anagen effluvium , where rapidly dividing hair follicle cells are damaged. Hair loss starts within weeks of chemotherapy initiation and is diffuse and non-scarring . Hair typically regrows within a few months after stopping chemotherapy.
  • ➤ Chemotherapy-induced hair loss is due to anagen effluvium , where rapidly dividing hair follicle cells are damaged.
  • ➤ anagen effluvium
  • ➤ Hair loss starts within weeks of chemotherapy initiation and is diffuse and non-scarring .
  • ➤ Hair loss starts within weeks of chemotherapy initiation
  • ➤ diffuse and non-scarring
  • ➤ Hair typically regrows within a few months after stopping chemotherapy.

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with dilated tortuous veins in the leg. He had a history of trauma 10 years back in the same limb. On examination, the dilated tortuous vein showed pulsatility. Most likely diagnosis in this patient will be? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) AV fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A history of trauma with the presence of dilated tortuous veins showing pulsatility strongly indicates an arteriovenous fistula due to the transmission of arterial pulsation to the veins

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with dyspnea and chest pain. Which of the following proves that she has aortic stenosis rather than aortic regurgitation? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume

options.label: B
options.text: Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve

options.label: C
options.text: Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption

options.label: D
options.text: Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aortic stenosis is characterized by increased pressure work (afterload) leading to higher myocardial oxygen consumption, distinguishing it from aortic regurgitation, which is associated with volume overload (preload).

questions.text: In the shown image, which one of the following is a source of vitamin B1? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B1 is primarily found in the aleurone layer of grains, which can be removed by polishing but is preserved in parboiled rice.

questions.text: After abstaining from alcohol for three days, a patient presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. In this case, what is the most likely diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: A 60-year post-menopausal obese lady presents with backache. She has a history of Colle’s fracture 1 year back. A DEXA scan shows a T score of less than - 2.5. Which of the following is false? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Elemental calcium of 1200mg/ day is recommended

options.label: B
options.text: Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium

options.label: C
options.text: Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered

options.label: D
options.text: Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year

questions.correct_answer: D. Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Management of Osteoporosis:
  • • Management of Osteoporosis:
  • • Elemental Calcium and Vitamin D: Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures. Bisphosphonates: Bisphosphonates such as Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid are commonly used to treat osteoporosis. These drugs help to slow down bone resorption, thus preserving bone density. The recommended duration of bisphosphonate therapy is generally 3-5 years, not limited to just 1 year. Studies have shown that longer-term use of bisphosphonates can continue to provide benefits in reducing the risk of fractures. However, the exact duration should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors and response to treatment. Teriparatide: Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates new bone formation. It is particularly beneficial in patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded well to bisphosphonates. When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.
  • • Elemental Calcium and Vitamin D: Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • • Elemental Calcium and Vitamin D:
  • • Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • • Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • • Bisphosphonates: Bisphosphonates such as Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid are commonly used to treat osteoporosis. These drugs help to slow down bone resorption, thus preserving bone density. The recommended duration of bisphosphonate therapy is generally 3-5 years, not limited to just 1 year. Studies have shown that longer-term use of bisphosphonates can continue to provide benefits in reducing the risk of fractures. However, the exact duration should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors and response to treatment.

Studies have shown that longer-term use of bisphosphonates can continue to provide benefits in reducing the risk of fractures. However, the exact duration should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors and response to treatment.

  • • Teriparatide: Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates new bone formation. It is particularly beneficial in patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded well to bisphosphonates. When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.

It is particularly beneficial in patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded well to bisphosphonates. When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.

  • • When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Elemental calcium of 1200mg/day is recommended: This statement is true. Adequate calcium intake is essential for bone health, especially in postmenopausal women.
  • • Option A. Elemental calcium of 1200mg/day is recommended:
  • • Option B. Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium: This statement is true. Vitamin D3 helps in the absorption of calcium and is recommended to be given along with calcium supplements.
  • • Option B. Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium:
  • • Option C. Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered: This statement is true. Starting with teriparatide helps build bone density, and following with bisphosphonates helps maintain the gains.

  • • Option D. Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bisphosphonates are typically recommended for a duration of 3-5 years in the treatment of osteoporosis, not limited to just 1 year.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury from the picture given below: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Incised looking lacerated wound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An incised looking lacerated wound is caused by blunt force trauma but appears similar to an incised wound due to its location and the characteristics of the tissue involved.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall from height. The patient reports no pain or injury, but on examination, there is blood at the tip of the urethral meatus. The patient is hemodynamically stable with no other injuries. The next step in management would be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ascending urethrogram

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To confirm urethral rupture in a patient with suspected urethral injury, an ascending urethrogram is the next step in management. Foley's catheterization should be avoided as it may exacerbate the injury.
  • ➤ To confirm urethral rupture in a patient with suspected urethral injury, an ascending urethrogram is the next step in management.
  • ➤ Foley's catheterization should be avoided as it may exacerbate the injury.

questions.text: What is the distance from the upper incisor teeth to the bronchial constriction of the esophagus? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The bronchial constriction of the esophagus occurs at the level where the left main bronchus crosses the esophagus, which is approximately 27 cm (11 inches) from the upper incisor teeth. This constriction is located at the T6 vertebral level. The esophagus has four sites of constriction: the cervical constriction at the cricopharyngeal junction (C6), the aortic constriction where the aortic arch crosses (T4), the bronchial constriction at the left main bronchus (T6), and the diaphragmatic constriction at the esophageal hiatus (T10). These constrictions are important to consider during endoscopic procedures or when evaluating patients with dysphagia.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. 15 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the cervical constriction at the cricopharyngeal junction.
  • • Option A. 15 cm
  • • Option B. 22 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the aortic constriction where the aortic arch crosses the esophagus.
  • • Option B. 22 cm
  • • Option D. 40 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the diaphragmatic constriction at the esophageal hiatus.
  • • Option D. 40 cm
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The bronchial constriction of the esophagus lies 27 cm (11 inches) from the upper incisor teeth, at the level where the left main bronchus crosses the esophagus (T6 vertebral level).

questions.text: Which of the following IV anesthetics acts on an NMDA receptor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ketamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ketamine is unique among IV anesthetics for its action as an NMDA receptor antagonist, leading to its characteristic dissociative anesthesia.
